metadata.title: AI Coding Agents: Operator Training Introduction
learningObjectives: Shift from teammate to tool mental model
Identify personal skill gaps to address

slides.title: AI Coding Agents: Operator Training
slides.subtitle: Learn to orchestrate autonomous code execution

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Welcome to operator training for AI coding agents. This isn't theory or templates—it's the systematic approach used in production to 10x output. The technology works, but most developers hit a frustration wall because they're using the wrong mental model. You'll learn to operate agents like CNC machines, not manage them like junior developers.
speakerNotes.discussion: Ask students: Who's used an AI coding assistant? What frustrated you most? Keep these responses in mind as we cover solutions.
speakerNotes.context: This course is built for senior engineers (3+ years experience) who know how to code and want to integrate agents into their workflow systematically.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's start by identifying the core problem that most developers face.

slides.title: The Operating Model Problem
content: Wrong mental model: AI agents as junior developers
You're waiting for understanding, fixing line-by-line, fighting context
Right mental model: AI agents as CNC machines for code
You specify the task precisely, delegate autonomously, validate output

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Most developers treat AI like a junior dev—checking every line, re-explaining concepts, managing mistakes. That's exhausting and defeats the purpose. Agents aren't teammates; they're tools that execute deterministically based on your specification. Like a CNC machine, if you program it correctly, it produces exactly what you asked for. If the output is wrong, the specification was wrong.
speakerNotes.discussion: Ask: How do you typically interact with AI assistants? Do you review every line? Do you explain yourself multiple times? Why? What changes if you think of it as a tool instead?
speakerNotes.context: In production, companies shipping 2x faster aren't rewriting agent output—they're specifying tasks precisely upfront. The better your specification, the less rework.
speakerNotes.transition: This course teaches you the operator mental model. Let's see what you'll actually learn.

slides.title: What This Course IS
content: Operator training for AI coding agents
Systematic methodology: Plan → Execute → Validate
Production-focused workflows for speed and quality
Practical techniques for unfamiliar codebases and debugging

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: This is hands-on operator training. You'll learn three core phases: Plan (break work into agent tasks, research architecture), Execute (craft precise prompts, run operations in parallel), and Validate (use tests as guardrails, review critically). These aren't tips—they're systematic approaches that scale.
speakerNotes.discussion: What problem would you want to solve first if you had better agent orchestration? Onboarding to unfamiliar code? Refactoring? Debugging?
speakerNotes.context: Unlike marketing pitches, this methodology is validated through real production use and through the fact that this course itself was built using these exact techniques.
speakerNotes.transition: Before we dive into methodology, let's be clear about what we're NOT teaching.

slides.title: What This Course ISN'T
content: Not AI theory or token prediction details
Not prompt templates or copy-paste solutions
Not a replacement for software fundamentals
Not for developers without production experience

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: This isn't a theoretical deep dive into how LLMs work—we cover internals only when they affect operation. We're not giving you templates because copying prompts doesn't build skill; understanding principles does. You still need to know architecture and design patterns. And if you haven't shipped production code, this course won't make sense.
speakerNotes.discussion: Does anyone come from a non-production background? Good—you'll want to strengthen fundamentals first. Everyone else: you're in the right place.
speakerNotes.context: Many AI courses fall into the trap of being too theoretical or too template-focused. We're not doing that.
speakerNotes.transition: So who is this course actually for? Let me tell you if you're the right audience.

slides.title: Who Should Take This Course
content: 3+ years of professional engineering experience
Already tried AI assistants and hit frustration points
Want faster delivery without sacrificing code quality
Need to understand unfamiliar codebases or debug issues
Care about production-readiness, not demos

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: You're the right fit if you have real production experience and you've already hit walls with AI assistants. You're frustrated because you know good code should be maintainable and well-tested—you're not a beginner getting excited about demos. You want to integrate agents into actual work, not just explore the technology.
speakerNotes.discussion: Raise your hand if you've used AI assistants. What was the specific frustration? Context limits? Low-quality code? Not understanding what you asked for? All of these are solvable with the right operator approach.
speakerNotes.context: By the end of this course, you should be comfortable delegating entire features to agents while maintaining architectural integrity and code quality.
speakerNotes.transition: Now let's talk about the specific methodology you'll learn.

slides.title: The Three-Phase Operating Model
slides.caption: Systematic operator workflow breaks complex tasks into autonomous agent execution.

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: The entire course revolves around three phases. Plan: you break down work, research the codebase, ground the agent in context. Execute: you craft precise prompts, delegate to sub-agents, parallelize work. Validate: you use tests as guardrails, review code critically, require evidence of correctness. These phases repeat for every feature, refactor, and bug fix.
speakerNotes.discussion: Which phase do you think most developers skip? (Usually planning and validation—they jump to execution and pay the price later.)
speakerNotes.context: This is the production workflow. Every successful agent deployment follows this cycle. Skipping any phase causes 5+ iterations instead of 1-2.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's be concrete about what you'll be able to do after mastering these three phases.

slides.title: What You'll Gain (Learning Outcomes)
content: Onboard to unfamiliar codebases 5-10x faster using agentic research
Refactor complex features reliably with test-driven validation
Debug production issues by delegating analysis to agents
Know when to use agents and when to code yourself

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: After this course, you won't just use agents faster—you'll think about delegation differently. You'll onboard to a new codebase in hours instead of days. You'll refactor fearlessly because you're using tests as guardrails. You'll debug issues faster by delegating log analysis to agents. Most importantly, you'll have the judgment to know when agents are the right tool and when you need to think through the problem yourself.
speakerNotes.discussion: Which of these four outcomes would have the biggest impact on your work right now? Onboarding speed? Debugging? Feature velocity?
speakerNotes.context: In production environments, the bottleneck isn't code writing—it's understanding, testing, and validation. Agents excel at code; humans excel at judgment.
speakerNotes.transition: Before you start, make sure you have the right foundation.

slides.title: Prerequisites for Success
content: 3+ years professional software engineering experience
Access to CLI-based coding agent (Claude Code, Copilot, etc)
Willingness to unlearn 'AI as teammate' thinking

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: You need production experience because the course assumes you understand architecture and design patterns. You need a CLI agent, not just a chat interface—that's how you scale operations. And you need to commit to the mental model shift. If you're expecting AI to 'understand' your codebase and hand-hold you, you'll be disappointed. If you're ready to operate a tool precisely, you'll see massive gains.
speakerNotes.discussion: Who has access to a CLI agent? If not, get setup with Claude Code or Copilot before the next session. If you're not sure about the mental model shift, that's the first thing to work through.
speakerNotes.context: The CLI agent is critical because it lets you parallelize work, script operations, and maintain context across multiple tasks. Chat interfaces don't give you that control.
speakerNotes.transition: Now let's talk about how to use this course effectively.

slides.title: How to Use This Course
content: Sequential learning: foundational concepts build on each other
Module 1: Tools and mental models (context and architecture)
Module 2: Methodology (prompting, grounding, workflows)
Module 3: Practical techniques (planning, testing, debugging)
Hands-on exercises on real codebases are mandatory

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Don't skip ahead. Module 1 teaches you how agents actually work and why context matters. Module 2 teaches the systematic methodology. Module 3 applies both to real-world scenarios. And you must work through exercises on actual codebases, not the examples. That's where the skill actually builds.
speakerNotes.discussion: What codebase would you want to apply these techniques to first? Onboarding to a new project? Refactoring a legacy module? That's your first exercise.
speakerNotes.context: Most people learn frameworks by reading, then fail when they try to apply them. We're flipping that: you learn by doing on real problems.
speakerNotes.transition: Before we close, I want to show you something important about how this course was built.

slides.title: This Course Practices What It Teaches
content: Curriculum developed entirely using AI-assisted workflows
Planned with systematic methodology, researched, validated critically
Podcast audio generated using Claude Code + Gemini
Proof that these techniques work on their own application

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: We didn't just write about operator training—we used operator training to build this course. The content structure, lesson progression, code examples, and documentation all came from the methodology you'll learn. The podcast versions with Alex and Sam? AI-generated voices and scripts, generated with the same techniques. This isn't marketing. It's validation. If these approaches can produce production-grade training material, they're robust enough for your codebase.
speakerNotes.discussion: What does it tell you about these techniques if we used them to build the course itself? Does that make you more confident in the methodology?
speakerNotes.context: Transparency matters. We're not claiming magic; we're showing you what's actually possible when you operate agents systematically.
speakerNotes.transition: You're ready. Let's move to Module 1 and start building your operating skills.
